physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. The design features several vertical panels with dense decorative motifs. The panel on the right features a vertical row of square diamonds in between the rows of interlocking triangles. The sarong is decorated with fluid tendrils and bird motifs. There are no signatures seen on the sarong.
sgcool_label_text: On the broad, vertical panel of this batik (or kepala), square and upright diamonds appear between the rows of interlocking triangles (or tumpal).  The bold, angular shapes on the kepala is enlivened by the fluid tendrils and bird motifs both on the two panels flanking the kepala and the main design field of the sarong, badan (or body).  Floral and bird motifs are set against diamond filler motifs on the badan, providing depth to the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.
